facts.text: Appellant Surajpal Singh employed in Police Department of Uttar Pradesh Government; started as constable on Rs. 13 per month from August 1, 1930.
In 1946, appellant's pay increased to Rs. 46 per month.
Appellant appointed Head constable on Rs. 50 per month in 1947.
Appellant officiated as Sub-Inspector of Police in 1948 and 1949 on Rs. 150 per month.
On March 1, 1949, appellant reverted to post of Head constable.
Between February 27, 1951, and September 9, 1952, appellant posted as Head constable attached to Sadar Malkhana, Kanpur.

Charge: Appellant dishonestly or fraudulently misappropriated or converted to own use articles seized in excise offences kept in Malkhana, including opium, bottles of liquor etc., in conspiracy with Bhagawat Singh and Gulab Singh.
Sum of Rs. 9,284-1-0 recovered on search of appellant's house on September 9 and 10, 1952; disproportionate to known sources of income.
Charges: 1. Conspiracy under s.120B IPC; 2. Criminal misconduct under s.5(1)(c) PCA r/w s.5(2); 3. Forgery under s.465 IPC re entry in Register of Properties.

Special Judge acquitted Bhagawat Singh and Gulab Singh; acquitted appellant on all charges except s.5(2) PCA, based solely on failure to account for Rs.9,284-1-0 disproportionate to income; held not guilty of dishonest misappropriation.
Special Judge sentenced appellant to 4 years rigorous imprisonment under s.5(2) PCA.
Allahabad High Court on March 27, 1958, in Criminal Appeal No. 785 of 1955, maintained conviction under s.5(2) PCA but reduced sentence to 2 years rigorous imprisonment.
Appellant gave explanation for possession of Rs.9,284-1-0, not accepted by courts below.

legal_issues.text: Whether conviction under s.5(2) of Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 by invoking presumption u/s.5(3) is correct when appellant acquitted on charge of criminal misconduct u/s.5(1)(c).

petitioner_arguments.text: Cannot convict under s.5(2) using presumption u/s.5(3) when acquitted on specific charge u/s.5(1)(c); scheme of s.5: (1) defines offence in categories (a)-(d), (2) punishes, (3) presumes for those offences; no charge under other categories.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 s.5(1)(c), s.5(2), s.5(3); C.S.D. Swamy v. The State

respondent_arguments.text: Appellate court can affirm conviction under s.5(2) by holding guilty of criminal misconduct under cl.(a) or cl.(d) of s.5(1).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 s.5(1)(a), s.5(1)(d), s.5(2)

court_reasoning.text: Accepts appellant's argument; presumption u/s.5(3) is rule of evidence applicable to charged offence u/s.5(1)(c); acquittal on that charge leaves no basis for presumption under other categories; s.5(3) does not create new offence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Offence punished u/s.5(2) or founded on s.5(3) presumption must be one of categories in s.5(1)(a)-(d); only (c) charged and failed.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes C.S.D. Swamy v. State: there were charges under (a) and (d), here only (c) and acquitted.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.5(3) empowers presumption in certain circumstances contrary to usual burden on prosecution.

court_reasoning.text: Appellate court cannot affirm on new case under (a) or (d) never alleged; prosecution case tied to misappropriation from entrusted property.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cannot evolve new case from vacuum without facts alleged.

holdings.text: Conviction under s.5(2) PCA invoking s.5(3) presumption invalid when acquitted on sole charged offence u/s.5(1)(c); no other charge to support presumption.

precedents_cited.relevance: Sub-s.3 of s.5 PCA lays down rule of evidence for presumption of guilt; in that case charges under (a) and (d), unlike here with only (c).

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines criminal misconduct (s.5(1)), punishes it (s.5(2)), presumption rule (s.5(3)); conviction under s.5(2) requires link to s.5(1) category charged.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Conspiracy and forgery charges, on which acquitted.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allows appeal by special leave; holds conviction under s.5(2) PCA incorrect as based on presumption without valid charged offence under s.5(1); sets aside conviction of lower courts.

key_quotes.text: "sub-s. 3 of s. 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 does not create a new offence but only lays down a rule of evidence which empowers the Court to presume the guilt of the accused in certain circumstances"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "the offence which is punished under sub-s. 2 or can be founded on the rule of presumption laid down in sub-s. 3 must be the offence of criminal misconduct of one or more of the categories mentioned in cls. a to d of sub-s. 1"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding limiting presumption to charged categories

key_quotes.text: "It is not open to the appellate Court to affirm the conviction of the Appellant on an entirely new case never suggested against the appellant at any earlier stage."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Prevents new case invention on appeal
